Well, you know, black women and their children have been bombarded with misogyny, violence and obscenity through public airwaves.

What we want is for these executives to meet with us in a respectful manner, hear what those grievances are and allow the women who are being hurt or harmed by these images to sit down with them and talk about more balance in their programming.
We're certainly not for censorship, but we want responsibility.
We have lots of rights, one of them including the freedom of speech.
But along with every freedom or every right in our country, we also have responsibility.
So that's what we are asking these media executives to do, is to exercise some responsibility.
While we believe in free speech, we also believe in decent speech.
The name Enough is Enough implies that there was a breaking point.
Was there one moment where you or other members who had been protesting said, this is it, this is the last straw?
Well, you know, the National Congress of Black Women has been working to eradicate this harmful, misogynistic and violent language and videos for nearly 15 years.
But I believe it was at the moment that we heard Imus refer to the young women from the Rutgers by a vulgar name, we decided that we'd had enough at that point.

And following that almost immediately, BET came out with a comic thing, you know, for children called ""Read a Book."" And it was so obscene, so vulgar, we decided that we could no longer sit by and we began picketing at the home of the CEO of BET.

We have tried many times to talk with them about their programming, but we've not been able to get their attention to the point that they would allow us to be participants in looking at what they're going to put out there.
And we're not trying to censor, but just to say let's have some balance here.
If you must put on this garbage, take it off the time that young children are watching it.
And also try to put on some positive things about women because black women, in particular, are having such a bad time.
We're being denigrated from all sides.
And we want some balance because black women play a big role in this country.
We've been secretary of state.
We've been secretary of labor, of energy.
We've been ambassadors.
We have helped to rear many of the people in this country to become what they are.
And we really don't deserve this kind of treatment.
Say the tactic of picketing outside private homes has been used by people who are opponents of abortion, people who are protesting sexual pedophiles.
It's a pretty strong tactic.
Do you ever question using it?
Well, we certainly are not there for the negative reasons.
We're there for positive reasons.
If we were able to sit down in the studio with Ms. Lee or with any of the other studio executives - as we have done with many, by the way.
And if they have listened to us and not just dismissed us as the CEO of BET has, there would be no need for us to go to her home to get her attention.
As you know, the walls of BET are very wide.
If we went to BET, we would not even get close to Ms. Lee.
She would not even know that we were there.
But at her home, she knows that we're there.
And we're not there for any violent reason.
We have told the police, we've told everyone, we will have no violence.
We will not do anything to try to break into her home or what have you.

We're just simply trying to get her attention to understand that this is a very serious issue, and we need to talk with her about programming, and she needs to be serious about making some changes and getting greater balance.
At what point do you allow people to make choices?

There are ways to bleep albums.
At what point do you think personal responsibility plays a role in this?
We're not just talking about blocking out.
We're talking about getting more favorable programming particularly where women are concerned.
We know that in the mainstream radio, there's not one single black woman who is heading up a radio.
And I don't think it's much worse for women of any kind, but certainly not for us.
We want the good things that we do to be out there, not just the negative things.
But we have no problem with people going to night clubs of that's what they want to do and have this kind of thing.
But we don't want just that harmful image about us out there.
And when it's out there for children, children grow up to believe they're gangsters and pimps and hustlers and all of those things.
And we know that we can do better.
We can do a lot better than we're doing to balance the programming.
That's all we're asking.
We're not asking them to take off all the negatives if they want to have negative.
But they also need to balance it with good.

It had good things on.
We had reasons to watch it.
Now, we don't.
